nodes.text: Bounds on the Quenched Pressure and Main
Eigenvalue of the Ruelle Op erator for
Brownian Type Potentials
Abstract
In this paper we consider a random potential derived from the
Brownian motion. We obtain upper and lower bounds for the ex-
pected value of the main eigenvalue of the associated Ruelle operator
and for its quenched topological pressure. We also exhibit an isomor-
phism b etween the space C (Ω) endowed with its standard norm and
a prop er closed subspace of the Skorokhod space which is used to ob-
tain a stochastic functional equation for the main eigenvalue and for
its asso ciated eigenfunction.
Key-words: Brownian motion, One-dimensional lattice, Quenched Pressure, Ran-
dom potentials, Ruelle operator, Thermodynamic formalism.
1 Intro duction
The basic idea of the Ruelle operator is based on the transfer matrix method
introduced by Kramers and Wannier and independently by Montroll to ex-
plicitly compute partition functions in Statistical Mechanics. This operator
was introduced in 1968 by David Ruelle [Rue68] and was used to describ e
lo cal to global prop erties of systems with infinite range interactions. Among
other things, Ruelle used this operator to prove the existence of a unique
DLR-Gibbs measure for a lattice gas system depending on infinitely many
co ordinates. The acronym DLR stands for Dobrushin, Lanford and Ruelle.
With the advent of the Markov partitions due to Y. Sinai, remarkable
applications of this op erator to Hyperbolic dynamical systems on compact
manifolds were further obtained by Ruelle, Sinai and Bowen, see [Rue68,
Sin72, Bow08]. Since its creation, this operator remains to have a great in-
fluence in many fields of pure and applied Mathematics. It is a powerful
tool to study topological dynamics, invariant measures for Anosov flows, sta-
tistical mechanics in one-dimension, meromorphy of the Zelberg and Ruelle
dynamical zeta functions, multifractal analysis, conformal dynamics in one
dimension and fractal dimensions of horseshoes, just to name a few. For
those topics, we recommend, resp ectively, [Bar11, Bow08, Bow79, Ma ˜n90,
MM83, PP90, Rue02, Sin72] and references therein.
In order to describe our contributions, we shall start by briefly recalling
the classical setting of the Ruelle operator. A comprehensive exposition of
this subject can be found in [Bal00, Bow08, PP90].
We now introduce the state space and the dynamics that will guide the
following discussions. In this paper, the state space will be the Bernoulli
space Ω = {0, 1}N and the dynamics is given by σ : Ω → Ω, the left shift
map. When top ological concept are concerned, the state space Ω is regarded
as a metric space where the distance between points x and y ∈ Ω is given by
d(x, y) = 1 2N , where N = inf{i ∈ N : xi ̸= yi}.
We shall remark that Ω is a compact metric space when endowed with this
metric. All of the results presented in this paper can be naturally extended to
{0, 1, . . . , m − 1}N , m ≥ 2, but for the sake of simplicity, we restrain ourselves
to the binary case. A summary of the changes required to study this more
general case are presented in Section 7.
Back to the case Ω = {0, 1}N , the set of all real continuous functions
defined over Ω will b e denoted by C (Ω) and the Ruelle transfer operator, or
simply the Ruelle operator, asso ciated to a continuous function f : Ω → R
will be denoted by Lf . This operator acts on the space of all continuous
functions sending φ to Lf (φ) which is defined for any x ∈ Ω by the following
expression
Lf (φ)(x) = (cid:88) a=0,1 exp(f (ax))φ(ax),
where ax ≡ (a, x1, x2 , . . .). The function f is usually called potential.
In this work a ma jor role will b e played by C γ (Ω), the space of γ -H¨older
continuous functions, with the H¨older exponent γ satisfying 0 < γ < 1/2.
This space is the set of all functions f : Ω → R satisfying
Hol(f ) = sup x,y∈Ω: x̸=y |f (x) − f (y)| d(x, y)γ < +∞.
Equipp ed with its standard norm ∥ · ∥γ given by C γ (Ω) ∋ f (cid:55)→ ∥f ∥γ ≡
∥f ∥∞ + Hol(f ), the space C γ (Ω) is a Banach space, see [PP90] for more
details.
Furthermore, we present the suitable version of the Ruelle-Perron-Fr¨ob e-
nius Theorem that will be required for our discussions. See [Bal00, Bow08,
PP90] for a proof.
Theorem A (Ruelle-Perron-Fr¨obenius, RPF). If f is a potential in C γ (Ω)
for some 0 < γ < 1, then Lf : C γ (Ω) → C γ (Ω) have a simple positive eigen-
value of maximal modulus λf with a corresponding strictly positive eigenfunc-
tion hf and a unique Borel probability measure νf on Ω such that,
i) the remainder of the spectrum of Lf : C γ (Ω) → C γ (Ω) is contained in
a disc of radius strictly smal ler than λf ;
ii) the probability measure νf satisfies L ∗f (νf ) = λf νf , where L ∗f denotes
the dual of the Ruelle operator;
iii) for al l continuous functions φ ∈ C (Ω) we have
lim n→∞ (cid:13) (cid:13) (cid:13) (cid:13) (cid:13) L n f (φ) λnf − hf (cid:90) Ω φ dνf (cid:13) (cid:13) (cid:13) (cid:13) (cid:13)∞ = 0.
Whereas in the classical theory of the Ruelle operator, f is some fixed
H¨older, Walters [Wal07, Bou01] or Bowen [Bow08, Wal01] potential, here we
are interested in obtaining almost certain results for random potentials.
Definition 1 (Random Potentials). Let (Ψ, F , P) be a complete probability
space. A random potential is a map X : Ψ × Ω → R satisfying for any fixed
x ∈ Ω that ψ (cid:55)→ X(ψ, x) is F -measurable. A random potential X is said to
be a continuous random potential if x (cid:55)→ X (ψ , x) ∈ C (Ω) for P-almost
al l ψ ∈ Ψ.
Although some of our results could be stated for a large class of random
potentials, we focus on the random potentials of Brownian typ e (see the next
section for the definition of such potentials).
When moving into the realm of random potentials the basic theory of
the Thermo dynamic Formalism needs to be reconstructed from scratch. In
[FS88] random potentials were considered and this is the setting of our work.
Latter, more general settings were introduced. The theory was extended to
cover countable random Markov subshifts of finite type, allowing randomness
to be considered also in the adjacency matrix, we refer the reader to [BG95,
Bog96, DKS08, FS88, GK00, Kif08, KL06, MSU11], for this more general
setting.
As mentioned above the randomness here is considered exclusively in the
potential. Since this is simpler setting, for the reader’s convenience we proved
here, in full details for the Brownian potential, that important quantities such
as the spectral radius, the top ological pressure and the main eigenvalue of
the Ruelle operator can be asso ciated to random variables with finite first
moment in Wiener spaces. At the end of Section 2 we explain how to obtain
similar results for Brownian potential using the general setting considered in
Working with random potentials, we are led to consider questions similar
in spirit to the ones we ask when studying disordered systems in Statistical
Mechanics, for instance the existence of annealed and quenched free energy
and pressure, respectively, see [MPV87]. Our approach provides a new way to
obtain the existence and finiteness of quenched topological pressure defined
P quenched (X ) ≡ E (cid:34) sup µ∈Pσ(Ω) (cid:26) h(µ) + (cid:90) Ω X dµ (cid:27)(cid:35) ,
(note that the existence of the rhs above is itself a deep question) as well
as the identity P quenched(X ) = E [limn→∞ n−1 log L nX (1)(σn (x))] , ∀x ∈ Ω for
a large class of continuous random potential X not invoking the classical
replica trick. On the other hand, despite the progress achieved with this
metho d, it has the disadvantage of not being able to exhibit explicitly these
quantities.
Our main results are Theorems 1, 2, the expression (3), and the bounds
for the quenched pressure in Section 6.
The paper is organized as follows. In Section 2 we intro duce the so-
called Brownian potential and we prove that the main eigenvalue for the
random Ruelle operator associated to the Brownian p otential almost surely
exists. We also prove in this section that phase transition for this random
potential, in the sense of the Definition 2, is almost surely absent. In Section
3 and 4 we prove a Banach isomorphism between C(Ω) and a certain closed
subspace of the Skorokhod space, denoted by D [0, 1]. With the help of this
isomorphism we obtain a stochastic functional equation satisfied by both
the main eigenvalue and its asso ciated eigenfunction. Then a representation
of the main eigenvalue in terms of the Brownian motion and a limit of a
quotient between linear combinations of log-normal random variables are
also obtained. Section 5 is devoted to obtain upper and lower bounds for
the exp ected value of the main eigenvalue and the main idea is the use of
the reflection principle of the Brownian motion to overcome the complex
combinatorial problem arising from the representation obtained in Section 4.
In Section 6 we use the results of Sections 2-5 to give a pro of of existence
and finiteness of the quenched topological pressure. In Section 7 we briefly
discuss some natural extensions of our results, as to more general alphab ets
and to other random potentials. We also explain the difficulties in improving
our estimates and obtaining the existence of the annealed pressure.
2 Brownian Type Potentials
Let {Bt : t ∈ [0, 1]} be the standard one-dimensional Brownian motion,
i.e., a stochastic process with continuous paths almost surely, stationary
indep endent increments and Bt ∼ N (0, t) for each t ≥ 0, see [KS91, Lig10].
The idea is to use the almost certain continuity of its paths t (cid:55)→ Bt to
define an almost certain continuous random p otential on the symbolic space
The construction of this random potential is as follows. We consider the
function (abusing notation) t : Ω → [0, 1] from the symbolic space to the
closed unit interval [0, 1], defined for each x ∈ Ω by the expression t(x) =
2−n xn . The Brownian p otential is the random mapping from Ω to
R given by
Ω ∋ x (cid:55)→ Bt(x).
Figure 1: Samples of the Brownian potential.
From the very definition of the Brownian motion follows that the Brown-
ian potential is almost certain a continuous potential over the symb olic space
Ω. Therefore we have almost certain a well defined Ruelle operator LBt(·)
sending C (Ω) to itself. This “random” operator takes a continuous function
φ to another continuous function LBt(·) (φ) that is given for each x ∈ Ω by
LBt(·) (φ)(x) = (cid:88) y∈Ω:σ(y)=x exp(Bt(y) )φ(y ). (1)
We observe that rhs of (1) let it clear that LBt(·) (φ)(x) is a random
variable, for any choice of x ∈ Ω and φ ∈ C (Ω).
Prop osition 1. The spectral radius λB of the random Ruel le operator LBt(·)
is a non-negative random variable.
Proof. Of course, the only issue here is about measurability and we show how
to overcome this by using the Gelfand Formula and expression (1). Indeed,
by applying iteratively the expression (1) one can see that L nBt(·) (φ)(x) is a
random variable for any choice of φ ∈ C (Ω) and x ∈ Ω. For any fixed n ∈ N
and φ ∈ C (Ω) there exists, by the definition of the supremum, a sequence
(xk ) in Ω such that ∥L nBt(·) (φ)∥∞ = limk→∞ |L nBt(·) (φ)(xk )| so proving that
∥L nBt(·) (φ)∥∞ is a random variable. Since the Gelfand’s formula ensures that
the spectral radius of LBt(·) is given by
λB = lim n→∞ (sup{∥L nBt(·) (φ)∥∞ : φ ∈ C(Ω) and ∥φ∥∞ = 1}) 1n
we can argue similarly as above to conclude that λB is a random variable.
Prop osition 2. The random variable λB is the main eigenvalue of the ran-
dom Ruelle operator LBt(·) almost surely. Moreover this operator has a posi-
tive continuous eigenfunction hB and, additionally, hB (x) is a random vari-
able, for each x ∈ Ω.
Proof. A typical tra jectory of the Brownian motion in the unit interval [0, 1]
is γ-H¨older continuous function for any γ < 1/2, see [KS91, Lig10]. A simple
computation shows that |t(x) − t(y)| ≤ d(x, y ), where d(x, y ) = 2−N and
N = inf {n : xj = yj for 1 ≤ j < n and xn ̸= yn }. Therefore almost certain
we have
|Bt(x) − Bt(y)| ≤ const.|t(x) − t(y)|γ ≤ const.(d(x, y ))γ .
So our random potentials x (cid:55)→ Bt(x) are almost certain γ-H¨older continuous
for any γ < 1/2. From the classical Ruelle-Perron-Fr¨obenius Theorem follows
that λB , the random spectral radius of LBt(·) , is actually the main eigenvalue
and it has geometric multiplicity one almost surely. From item iii) of Theorem
A we have for each x ∈ Ω that
λ−nB · L nBt(·) (1)(x) → h(x).
Since the lhs above is a random variable it follows that h(x) is also a random
variable.
Before proceed we recall some elementary facts about dual of the Ruelle
operator asso ciated to a deterministic general continuous potential. As we
mentioned before (Ω, d) is a compact metric space so one can apply the Riesz-
Markov Theorem to prove that C ∗ (Ω) is isomorphic to Ms(Ω), the space of all
signed Radon measures. Therefore we can define L ∗f , the dual of the Ruelle
operator, as the unique continuous map from Ms (Ω) to itself satisfying for
each γ ∈ Ms(Ω) the following identity
(cid:90) Ω Lf (φ) dγ = (cid:90) Ω φ d(L ∗f γ) ∀φ ∈ C(Ω). (2)
From the p ositivity of Lf follows that the map γ (cid:55)→ L ∗f (γ)/L ∗f (γ)(1)
sends the space of all Borel probability measures P (Ω) to itself. Since
P (Ω) is convex set and compact in the weak topology (which is Haus-
dorff in this case) and the mapping γ (cid:55)→ L ∗f (γ )/L ∗f (γ )(1) is continuous,
the Tychonoff-Schauder Theorem ensures the existence of at least one Borel
probability measure νf such that L ∗f (νf ) = L ∗f (νf )(1)νf . The eigenvalue
λf ≡ L ∗f (νf )(1) is positive and equals to the spectral radius of Lf and there-
fore indep endent of the choice of the fixed point νf , see [Bal00, Bow08, PP90].
If X is a continuous random potential, then the Ruelle operator LX
sends C(Ω) to itself almost surely. We claim that for any continuous random
potential X the spectral radius of the operator LX , denoted by λX is a
random variable. In fact, the claim follows from the arguments given in the
pro of of Proposition 1 replacing Bt(·) by X .
Definition 2 (Phase Transition). Let X be a continuous random potential
and λX the random spectral radius of LX . We say that the random potential
X does not present phase transition if the eigenvalue problem L ∗X ν = λX ν
has a unique solution in P (Ω) almost surely. Otherwise, we say that X
presents phase transition.
Corollary 1 (Absence of Phase Transition for Brownian Potentials). Al-
most surely the dual of the Ruelle operator L ∗Bt(·) has one eigenprobability
associated to λB .
Proof. From the Theorem 1 follows that λB is both the spectral radius and
the main eigenvalue of LBt(·) . So the corollary follows from the almost certain
γ -H¨older continuity of the mapping Ω ∋ x (cid:55)→ Bt(x), obtained in the proof of
Theorem 1, together with the item ii) of Theorem A.
Let us denote by D the subset of the unit interval [0, 1] such that all of its
points have exactly two distinct binary expansion representations, i.e.,
If t(x) ∈ D then there is a unique y ∈ Ω \ {x} such that t(x) = t(y).
Moreover such x and y are always comparable in the lexicographic order.
When x is smaller than y in this order we indicate this by using the notation
x ≺Lex y.
We now introduce a proper subset of the Skorokhod space that will play
a fundamental role in this section. More details on the Skorokho d space
can b e found in [Bil99]. The functions b elonging to the subspace mentioned
above are c`adl`ag on the unit interval but only allowed to jump on the set
D . We use the convenient notation D [0, 1] to denote this subspace and it is
characterized as follows
D [0, 1] ≡    F : [0, 1] → R : F is continuous in [0, 1] \ D and ∀t ∈ D the left limit lims↑t F (s) exists; the right limit lims↓t F (s) = F (t).    .
We want to relate this space to C (Ω) and to this end we intro duce the
following linear operator Θ : D [0, 1] → C (Ω) which sends a function F ∈
D [0, 1] to a function f ∈ C (Ω) whose its definition is
• f (x) = F (t(x)) if x /∈ t−1 (D ) and
• if x ∈ t−1 (D ) then there exists a unique y ∈ Ω \ {x} such that
t(x) = t(y ). If x ≺Lex y we put f (x) = lims↑t(x) F (s) and f (y) =
lims↓t(y) F (s) = F (t(y )).
The linearity of Θ is obvious, but the statement Θ(F ) ∈ C (Ω) whenever
F ∈ D [0, 1] requires a proof and this is the content of the next proposition.
Prop osition 3. For every F ∈ D [0, 1] we have that Θ(F ) ∈ C(Ω).
Proof. Let x ∈ Ω be an arbitrary point and F ∈ D [0, 1]. In order to prove
the continuity of Θ(F ) at x we split the analysis in two cases: whether F is
continuous or not in t(x). Supp ose that F is continuous in t(x). In this case
indep endently whether t(x) b elongs or not to D we have Θ(F )(x) = F (t(x)).
Given ε > 0 follows from the continuity of F that there is δ > 0 such that
if |s − t(x)| < δ then |F (s) − F (t(x))| < ε. From the continuity of t it
is possible to find η > 0 such that if d(y , x) < η then |t(x) − t(y )| < δ .
Supp ose by contradiction that Θ(F ) is not continuous at x. So there is a
sequence yn ∈ Ω such that yn → x but |Θ(F )(yn ) − Θ(F )(x)| = |Θ(F )(yn ) −
F (t(x))| ≥ ε for all n ∈ N. Because of the previous observations for n
large enough Θ(F )(yn) ̸= F (t(yn)) otherwise we reach a contradiction. So
the only possibility is Θ(F )(yn) = lims↑t(yn ) F (s) for all n ≥ n0. Again, we
reach a contradiction since for large enough n we have t(yn ) close to t(x)
and therefore by taking s close enough to t(x) we have F (s) close to F (t(x))
which is a contradiction with |Θ(F )(yn ) − F (t(x))| ≥ ε.
Now we assume that F has a jump at t(x). In this case by the definition
of D [0, 1] there exist exactly one point y ∈ Ω \ {x} such that t(x) = t(y).
We give the argument for x ≺Lex y on the other case the analysis is similar.
Note that
From the definition we have
Θ(F )(x) = lim s↑t(x) F (s).
Given ε > 0 there is δ > 0 such that for all s satisfying t(x) − δ < s ≤ t(x) we
have |F (s) −Θ(F )(x)| < ε. Note that for every z ∈ Ω such that d(z, x) ≤ 2n+1
we have t(z) ≤ t(x). By taking z close enough to x and proceed similarly to
the previous case one can show that Θ(F )(z ) is close to Θ(F )(x), thus proving
the continuity of Θ(F ) at x. Since x is arbitrary the proof is complete.
Theorem 1. The operator Θ is a Banach isomorphism (linear isometry)
between the Banach spaces (D [0, 1], ∥ · ∥∞) and (C (Ω), ∥ · ∥∞ ).
Proof. We first construct the inverse operator Θ−1 and then we proceed to
show that Θ is an isometry.
Let f ∈ C (Ω) be an arbitrary continuous function. If s ∈ [0, 1] \ D
we define F (s) = f (t−1 (s)). If s ∈ D then t−1(s) = {x, y} with x ̸= y .
If x ≺Lex y we put F (s) = f (y). We claim that F ∈ D [0, 1]. Indeed, if
s ∈ [0, 1] \ D , then s has a unique binary expansion t−1(s) = (x1 , . . . , xn, . . .).
For each n ∈ N and j = 1, . . . , 2n we consider the following collection of open
intervals
I jn = (cid:18) j − 1 2n , j 2n (cid:19)
Note that D ∪ {0, 1} = ∪n≥1 ∪2nj=1 ∂ I jn . Note that if s ∈ [0, 1]\D , then s
belongs to the interior of infinitely many I jn’s. Given ε > 0 there is δ > 0 such
that for all y ∈ Ω satisfying d(t−1 (s), y ) < δ we have |f (t−1(s)) − f (y)| < ε.
As mentioned b efore we can cho ose n as large as we please so that s ∈ I jn ,
for some j = 1, . . . , 2n. From the definition of I jn the first n terms of the
binary expansion of any r ∈ I jn coincides with x1 , . . . , xn. For n such that
2−n < δ we have d(t−1(s), t−1 (r)) < δ and therefore for all r ∈ I jn we have
|F (r) − F (s)| ≤ maxz∈t−1 (r) |f (z ) − f (x)| < ε.
Suppose that t(x) ∈ D and {x, y} = t−1(x). Without loss of generality
we can assume that x ≺Lex y. For n ≥ n0 we have t(x) ∈ ∂ I jn ∩ ∂ I j+1n for
a unique value of j ∈ {1, . . . , 2n }. Every element in t−1(I jn ) has its first n
digits in the binary expansion equals to x1 , x2, . . . , xn . Therefore some small
neighborhood of x is sent by t in I jn ∪ {t(x)}. From the continuity of f at x it
follows that the small neighborhood defined ab ove is sent in a ε neighborhood
of f (x) which proves the existence of the left limit of F at t(x). The right
continuity of F at t(x) ∈ D is proved in similar way.
Notice that the argument in the two previous paragraphs also proves that
the mapping
C (Ω) ∋ f → Fs → (cid:40)f (t−1 (s)), if s ∈ [0, 1] \ D ;f (y), if t−1(s) = {x, y} and x ≺Lex y .
is a left inverse of Θ. Of course, Θ is right inverse of this operator so Θ is a
bijection.
Remains to prove that Θ is an isometry. From its very definition we have
If the supremum above is attained at certain p oint s ∈ [0, 1] \ D , take x ∈ Ω
such that t(x), then we have ∥F ∥∞ = |F (s)| = |Θ(F )(x)| ≤ ∥Θ(F )∥∞. If
the supremum is not attained for some s ∈ D the conclusion is analogous,
otherwise ∥F ∥∞ = limn→∞ limr↑sn |F (r)| = limn→∞ |Θ(F )(xn)|, where xn is
the smallest point, with resp ect to the lexicographic order, in t−1 (sn ) and
the proposition follows.
Remark 1 (Wiener Spaces). Recal l that the classical Wiener space on the
closed unit interval [0, 1], notation W [0, 1], is the set of al l real continuous
functions F : [0, 1] → R such that F (0) = 0. Consider the closed subspace of
C (Ω) given by
W (Ω) ≡ {f ∈ C (Ω) : f (0∞) = 0, f (x) = f (y) whenever t(x) = t(y)},
where the mapping t : Ω → R was previously defined. It is easy to see that
for every F ∈ W [0, 1] its composition with t give us a mapping F ◦ t ∈ W (Ω).
Moreover the linear mapping F (cid:55)→ F ◦ t is an isometry from W [0, 1] to W (Ω).
4 Sto chastic Functional Equation for λBλBλB
In this section we apply the results above obtained. The idea is to obtain
a stochastic functional equation using the operator Θ and Proposition 2 to
semi-explicit representation of the main eigenvalue λB of the random Ruelle
operator LBt(·) .
Since hB is a continuous function almost surely, we can asso ciate to it a
c`adl`ag process {Xs : 0 ≤ s ≤ 1} so that Θ(X(·)) = hB . By simple algebraic
manipulation we can see that t(0x) = t(x)/2 and t(1x) = 1/2 + t(x)/2. By
applying the inverse of the operator Θ on both sides of the above equation
we get the following stochastic functional equation
exp(B t 2 )X t 2 + exp(B 1 2 + t2 )X 12 + t2 = λB Xt.
Now we have to play with the properties of the Brownian motion and
the Ruelle op erator to obtain the law of the main eigenvalue. Recalling that
B0 = 0 almost surely, so we get from the sto chastic functional equation that
X0 + exp(B 1 2 )X 1 2 = λB X0 .
Therefore we get by isolating the eigenvalue (recall that Xs > 0 for each
s ∈ [0, 1]) the following equality a.s.
By using again the operator Θ one can see that X0 = hB (0, 0, . . .) and
Theorem A we have almost certain
From where we conclude that
5 Bounds on the Exp ected Value of λBλBλB
In the deterministic case, when the potential is assumed to have H¨older,
Walters or Bowen regularity, it is easy to obtain lower and upper b ounds of
the main eigenvalue of the Ruelle operator by using the supremum norm of
the potential. We recall that when the potential have such regularity the
main eigenvalue do exists and is actually equals to the sp ectral radius.
Since here we are considering random potentials lower and upp er bounds
for the exp ected values, with respect to the Wiener measure, of the spectral
radius is a natural question to ask.
Opposed to the deterministic case the supremum norm of Bt(·) by it-
self do es not help in finding bounds to the spectral radius. The reason is
sup{|Bt(x)| : x ∈ Ω} is an unb ounded random variable. The representation
of λB obtained in the last section is not suitable to take expectations and very
hard to bound due its complex combinatorial nature. Therefore a different
approach is needed to b ound the expected value of main eigenvalue and the
idea is based on the reflection principle of the Brownian motion.
Theorem 2. Let λB be the random variable defining the spectral radius of
the random Ruel le operator LBt(·) . Then λB has finite first moment, with
respect to the Wiener measure, and moreover
Proof. We begin with the lower bound. To lighten the notation we use the
symbol 1∞ to denote the constant sequence (1, 1, 1, . . .). By the definition of
the supremum we have

sup φ:∥φ∥∞ =1 ∥L nBt(·) (φ)∥∞ = sup φ:∥φ∥∞=1 sup x∈Ω |L nBt(·) (φ)(x)| = sup φ:∥φ∥∞ =1 sup x∈Ω | (cid:88) a1,...,an exp( n−1 (cid:88) j=0 Bt(σ j (a1 ...anx)))φ(σ j (a1 . . . anx))| ≥ exp n−1 (cid:88) j =0 Bt(1∞ ) ≥ exp(nB1 ).
By taking the n-th root, the limit when n → ∞ and the expectation in the
above inequality we get that
E[λB] ≥ E[exp(B1 )] = exp(1/2).
To get the upp er bound we will take advantage of the reflection principle
of the Wiener pro cess. We first observe that

sup φ:∥φ∥∞=1 ∥L nBt(·) (φ)∥∞ ≤ sup x∈Ω |L nBt(·) (1)(x)| = sup x∈Ω (cid:88) a1,...,an exp n−1 (cid:88) j =0 Bt(σj (a1...an x)) ≤ (cid:88) a1,...,an sup x∈Ω exp n−1 (cid:88) j =0 Bt(σj (a1...an x)) ≤ 2n exp(n max{Bt : 0 ≤ t ≤ 1}).
By taking the n-th root and the limit when n → ∞ in the last inequality we
get λB ≤ 2 exp(M1), where M1 ≡ max{Bt : 0 ≤ t ≤ 1}. From the reflection
principle of the Wierner process it follows that
E[λB ] ≤ 2E[exp(M1 )] ≤ 4 · E[exp B1 ] = 4 exp(1/2).
6 Existence and Finiteness of the Quenched
Pressure
By using the γ-H¨older regularity of the Brownian p otential x (cid:55)→ Bt(x) and a
classical result of Thermodynamic formalism, we have almost certain
log λB = P (Bt(·)) = sup µ∈Pσ(Ω) (cid:26) h(µ) + (cid:90) Ω Bt(·) dµ (cid:27) ,
where P (·) is the top ological pressure, Pσ (Ω) is the set of all Borel probabil-

From (3) we know that λB = 1 + exp(B1/2)(X1/2/X0), and X1/2 /X0 ≥ 0.
Therefore we can conclude that log λB is non-negative random variable and
its expected value with respect to the Wiener measure is well defined, at least
as an extended real number.
Finally, by using the elementary inequality log λB ≤ λB and the Theorem
2 we have that E[log λB ] < +∞, thus proving the finiteness of the quenched
pressure. Using once more the γ-H¨older regularity of the Brownian potential
we have almost certain that
log λB = lim n→∞ 1 n log L nBt(·) (1)(σ n(x)), ∀x ∈ Ω
and therefore
P quenched (Bt(·) ) ≡ E[log λB ] = E (cid:20) lim n→∞ 1 n log L nBt(·) (1)(σ n (x)) (cid:21) .
Finally, by the Theorem 2 and the Jensen Inequality we get

7 Concluding Remarks
As mentioned, all the results presented in this paper can extended to the
space Ω = {0, . . . , m − 1}N. For such state spaces the map t : Ω → [0, 1] is
given by (x1 , x2 . . . ) (cid:55)→ (cid:80)n≥1 m−nxn . Analogous arguments can be used to
prove the Prop osition 1 and Prop osition 2. In the Section 3, the arguments
would be completely analogous, only changing appropriately the set D .
In the Section 4, we would have a subtle change in the stochastic func-
tional equation. Now we have for every a ∈ {0, . . . , m − 1} and x ∈ Ω,
t(ax) = a/m + t(x)/m, so a slightly different stochastic functional equation
shows up exp(Bt/m)Xt/m + exp(B1/m+t/m )X1/m+t/m = λB Xt. Thus, by taking
t = 0, we recover the representation of the main eigenvalue
The technique employed in Theorem 2 provided the following bounds
Therefore, by using the same arguments, one can also prove the existence
and finiteness of the Quenched Pressure on this case.
Another natural question is whether we could study another random po-
tential defined by a continuous time stochastic process other than a Brow-
nian Motion. Note that the only property of the Brownian Motion used to
guarantee the existence of the main eigenvalue is the almost certain H¨older
continuity of the paths (in fact this is required only in [0, 1]\D ), which is
not an exclusive property of Brownian Motion. In the functional stochastic
equation, we only used that B0 = 0 almost surely, but for the general case
all that is required is to add a constant to the potential. Here we used the
reflection principle and the stationarity of the increments to bound E[λB ]
which also follow for some other pro cesses. Nevertheless if one has another
technique to guarantee its finiteness, the general sequence described in the
article still holds and the existence and finiteness of the Quenched Pressure
is still guaranteed. Therefore, the natural candidate to extend the results is
Fractional Brownian motion, which indeed leads to very analogous results.
The obstacle one faces to obtain tighter lower b ounds for E[λB ] is of
combinatorial nature and the complicated sums of dependents log-normal
random variables that appear in the calculations and have to be controlled.
Some informal computations suggest that the annealed pressure is also well
defined for Brownian typ e p otential and p ossibly given by log(ess supλB), but
unfortunately the techniques developed here seem not so helpful in attacking
this problem.
